posts.cooked:
I want to use PathPlanner to drive for autonomous on my tank-drive robot this year, which my team has never done before. Since I only have 1 camera facing the rear of the robot (our shooter is faced behind us, and is in a fixed angle). Because of this, I want to use PathPlanner to compensate for the lack of detection of the notes.

For now, our autonomous code consists of shooting a preloaded note, and then using PID to drive a multitude of lines towards the next note and back to the speaker.

I’ve tried to follow PathPlanner’s docs as best as possible, but I seem to have some issues:

My robot won’t log its behavior We use NEOs for the drivetrain, so we use URCL, like the PathPlanner docs state

My robot won’t log its behavior

We use NEOs for the drivetrain, so we use URCL, like the PathPlanner docs state

We have not done any sort of SysID this is new to me, and I believe it was necessary, but because my robot isn’t logging data, I can’t make use of it image 829×176 11 KB

We have not done any sort of SysID

this is new to me, and I believe it was necessary, but because my robot isn’t logging data, I can’t make use of it image 829×176 11 KB

image 829×176 11 KB

image 829×176 11 KB

Simulations were unable to reach correctly follow the paths I’ve drawn I used the values 1.2 and 0.7 for beta and zeta of the RAMSETE controller. Although these were the best values I could find, these were still limited. In some auton routines, the robot would start to turn violently left and right instead of moving.

Simulations were unable to reach correctly follow the paths I’ve drawn

I used the values 1.2 and 0.7 for beta and zeta of the RAMSETE controller. Although these were the best values I could find, these were still limited. In some auton routines, the robot would start to turn violently left and right instead of moving.

PathPlannerLib requires a method that drives a given chassis speed, and I’m not sure how to implement this What I tried doing in simulations was to convert the chassis speed to wheelspeeds with the DifferentialDriveKinematics class, and then divide each of those speeds by the observed max velocity, and then input those values into the DifferentialDrive.tankdrive() method image 1068×212 14.2 KB

PathPlannerLib requires a method that drives a given chassis speed, and I’m not sure how to implement this

What I tried doing in simulations was to convert the chassis speed to wheelspeeds with the DifferentialDriveKinematics class, and then divide each of those speeds by the observed max velocity, and then input those values into the DifferentialDrive.tankdrive() method image 1068×212 14.2 KB

image 1068×212 14.2 KB

image 1068×212 14.2 KB

My competition is in 2 days, is it even worth the effort to fix this up now? All suggestions are greatly appreciated.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
You have a lot of different things in this topic. First, it would be really helpful if you could share all of your code, preferably as a link to a GitHub repo.

Driving paths:

You didn’t share your code, but I think you’re on the right track with driveChassisSpeeds . The chassisSpeeds object will be in meters per second, so if your tankDrive method expects duty cycle, you’ll need to do a conversion.

A more advanced (and accurate) way to drive would be with closed-loop velocity control. This is where you would use SysID values for feedforward, and you’d need to tune PID to get the right velocity. The Trajectory Tutorial covers some of this.

SysID and logging:

Does your SysID routine run, but you are unable to find the logs, or is the routine not even running?

Can you provide more information on why you think URCL is not logging? The log files should be on the roboRIO or on a USB drive you plugged into the roboRIO. If it’s not logging, maybe you are out of space on the robotRIO or the USB stick is full or not recognized (formatted incorrectly.) More details will help us troubleshoot with you.

link_counts.title: Trajectory Tutorial Overview — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
Thanks, Heres the link to the code: GitHub - Team5599/Robot2024: Offical code for 2024's FRC robot for FIRST CRESCENDO! presented by HAAS.

I’m not quite sure how or why, but it seems that data logging worked for one day, and doesn’t work anymore. I’m not quite sure why. The logs folder was only updating yesterday, but not today. But yes, SysID ran without logging anything (or i just couldn’t find it in the logs folder)

link_counts.title: GitHub - Team5599/Robot2024: Offical code for 2024's FRC robot for FIRST CRESCENDO! presented by HAAS.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: It looks like you don’t have enough space for logs. You could try clearing them by reimaging the rio.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: The messages in your picture are pretty clear, the rio is low on space so it’s not logging. Logging internally to the roboRIO is not recommended. You should consider plugging a FAT32 formatted flash drive into the roboRIO’s USB port.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Reimaging is the “nuclear option”, but it would work. You could also log into the roboRIO with FTP or SSH and delete the files from /home/lvuser/logs

link_counts.title: roboRIO FTP — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: So then whenever I run the robot, it attempts to save in the roborio AND the logs folder of my robot code?

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
karamatH:

In some auton routines, the robot would start to turn violently left and right instead of moving.

Make sure your gyro is oriented such that counterclockwise positive, the correct motors correspond to the right and left sides of the robot, and that the units are right.

In general the method of using a scale factor is a good starting place (you’re basically doing a velocity feedforward), but you will probably have to add PID to get accurate path following.

We using beta = 7, zeta = 1.3, which I would not generally recommend (beta is too high which is causing some issues), but I would try increasing your beta at least to the default of 2. Also, start with a path that is straight forward and back with no turns.

It’s hard to help you without logging working. As other have said, you probably need to delete existing logs, which you can do with the WPILib log tool.

I would say based on where you are now, I would also be concerned about you finishing by the regional. I would definitely not want you to give up, but this may be best for an offseason project.

Here is our code, if it helps:

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Logging runs on the roboRIO, so I’m not sure what you mean by the logs folder of your robot code. When the program is running on the robot, it will try to log to an external USB drive (connected to the roboRIO) first, then it will try to write to the roboRIO’s storage.

The only time you would get logs on your laptop would be if you were running the simulation.

I did not know that at all. This whole time I was under the impression that running the robot updated the logs folder, but I never noticed that it only updated from simulations only. Thank you for pointing that out!

Besides that, if I have a flashdrive connected to the roborio, all the necessary files and logs will be saved and then I can just follow the docs on SysID, correct?

this actually helps a lot, thanks!

I’ll send updates as this goes on during competition. Once again, thanks!

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Glad to hear it.

One more tip:

Do

at the beginning of the code. The default filtering settings for internal encoder velocity will average a large number of encoder samples taken infrequently, leading to a very large delay.
